As we entered the historical era populations in many places would have been under great pressure and only hanging on where people found it hard to hunt

text: @guyshrubsole @GeorgeMonbiot @DrKateSpencer @EnvAgency The contaminated land fund dried up completely a few years ago. Councils very unlikely to look for these sites when they can't afford to clean them up.
RT @guyshrubsole: @RachSalv @GeorgeMonbiot I've been to some of the leaking coastal landfills with @DrKateSpencer that she's been investiga…

@guyshrubsole @GeorgeMonbiot @DrKateSpencer @EnvAgency I'm hearing this a lot. There are a number of sites that look as though they should be part 2A (and so EA responsibility) but they haven't been designated for one reason or another...

Classic ‘landfill erosion’. In over a decade of river/coastal engineering, have seen this dozens of times.

Every time I see this, it’s someone else’s problem. 

@EnvAgency @NatResWales get it fixed. Keep the receipt. Sell the debt. Polluter pays.

Cry me a river. https://t.co/t222IIdT44

urls.title: A study exploring the pressures on Seagrass Meadows in Plymouth Sound.
urls.description: My name is Abigail Cundell and I am a final year student conducting research for my BSc Environmental Science dissertation at the University of Plymouth. This survey is exploring the pressures faced by seagrass meadows within Plymouth Sound and how different water based activities influence said pressures. If you are a user of Plymouth Sound under any of the following categories, it would be a great help to the research if you could kindly spare a few minutes to complete the following questionnaire. All results recorded are anonymous and the data will only be used within my dissertation. You may exit the questionnaire at anytime. For any extra information or questions please contact: abigail.cundell@students.plymouth.ac.uk Thank you!
